titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Hans Caspar Syz Papers
titlestmt.author: by J. Josephine Fueser

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:40

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, reading notes, writings and research materials relating primarily to Hans C. Syz's career as secretary and president of the Lifwynn Foundation. The papers provide information on the formation and development of the Lifwynn Foundation, as well as research and writing by staff members and students. Syz's work as a psychiatrist in New York and Baltimore hospitals is also documented, as are his activities as a collector of 18th-century Western European porcelain.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research. Materials in Boxes 77 and 78 and folder 91 in CF5 are restricted until June 1, 2026 for reasons of privacy.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by Stephen B. Syz and John D. Syz for materials authored or otherwise produced by their father Hans Syz. Requests for permission to publish should be directed to Stephan B. Syz. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Hans Caspar Syz Papers. Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the estate of Hans Syz, 1992-1994. Gift of Dr. Lloyd Gilden, 2017.

relatedmaterial.head: Related material
relatedmaterial.p: Trigant Burrow Papers (MS 1370). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.
Lifwynn Foundation Records (MS 1681). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Hans Caspar Syz papers document Syz's career as a psychiatrist and scholar, and highlight his research and professional activities as secretary (1927-1950) and president (1951-1991) of the Lifwynn Foundation. Through Syz's extensive correspondence, notes, reflections and writings, the papers document the development of the foundation from its inception as an experimental community in 1923, through many changes in its mandate and membership, until Syz's death in 1991. They chronicle Syz's efforts to publicize and promote the foundation's alternative approaches to mental health and interpersonal conflict. Researchers interested in the establishment and work of the Foundation will find it helpful to use this collection in conjunction with the Trigant Burrow Papers and the Lifwynn Foundation Records in Manuscripts and Archives.

The papers are organized into six series. Aside from Series VI, Ceramics files, which relates to Syz's activities as a prominent ceramics collector, the papers all relate to Syz's activities as a psychiatrist. General Files, Series I, which includes correspondence and memoranda of meetings documents Syz's contacts in the psychiatric and psychoanalytic communities. Series II, Notes, and III, Writings and Research Materials, which constitute one half of the collection, traces Syz's intellectual development, both in conjunction with and independent from Burrow. Series IV, Clinical Files, consists primarily of case notes and clinical observations, which document the traditional approaches to psychiatric work Syz encountered in hospital clinics in Baltimore and New York. Series V, Lifwynn Foundation Files, record the day-to day administration and ongoing research of the foundation and its staff.

There is only a small amount of material in the papers representing Syz's years as a medical student in Zürich, Munich and Geneva. Limited correspondence with Alfred Alder, Eugen Bleuler, Ludwig Binswanger and Oskar Pfister documents Syz's contacts and interests during this period (Series I). Syz's book Of Being and Of Meaning is based upon philosophical and mystical reflections recorded during his years in Switzerland. Notes from this period can be found in Series II, while manuscripts for the book are found in Series III. Syz's psychophysiological research, psychiatric practice and instruction under Adolf Meyer at the Henry Phipps Psychiatric Clinic of the Johns Hopkins University is documented in Series III and IV.

Several sources of information outline Syz's own professional affiliations. Series V contains a compilation of biographical data on Syz. Series IV and several correspondence files in Series I document Syz's work in major New York hospitals. Conference notes found in Series V give an indication of Syz's involvement with numerous professional organizations, as do the correspondence files pertaining to these organizations in Series I.

There are numerous sources for researchers interested in the establishment, ideals and early activities of Burrow's experimental community in Series I, II, and V. Correspondence in Series I, Syz's autobiographical notes in Series II, and staff papers and inter-office correspondence of Series V depict a closely-knit and highly dedicated group of students and staff. In the first two decades of the Lifwynn Foundation's life, these included Trigant Burrow and his family, Charles Shields (associate), Charles Baker Thompson (associate), Alfreda Payson Sill (student and manager of facilities), her daughter Alfreda Sill Galt (student, later Secretary), her husband William Egleston Galt (associate), Miriam Bredow (staff), Rosalind Bruce (student), Aimee and Flora Guggenheimer (students and volunteers), Nelly Holljes (student) and Florence Weingartner (staff).

The activities of the foundation during the 1950s can be traced through the work of two active associates, Lloyd Gilden and Björn Merker, in files in series I and IV. The foundation's work to systematically distribute Burrow's publications, as well as their own interpretations and extensions of his work, can be seen in correspondence with numerous individuals and communities concerned with psychosocial interventions in intergroup conflict. Syz's colleague Alfreda Galt, who succeeded him as secretary of the foundation, initiated much of this correspondence, which is filed in Series V. For correspondence documenting the attention paid to Burrow's work in the late 1950s by a new generation of psychologists and therapists interested in group processes, consult the files in Series I for discussions with colleagues such as Alfred Korzybski, J.L. Moreno, S.H. Foulkes, Nathan Ackerman, and Nina Bull. These files shed light on Burrow's influence on fields such as family therapy and group psychoanalysis.
Acknowledgements

The Hans Caspar Syz Papers were a gift of the estate of Hans Syz. Manuscripts and Archives appreciates the work done by Penny White of the Lifwynn Foundation, who initially organized the papers and prepared them for transfer to Yale University.
Funding for the processing of these papers was made possible through the generosity of the estate of Hans Syz.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Hans Caspar Syz, M.D., was born on August 1, 1894, in Zürich, Switzerland, to John and Clara Schindler Syz. He studied medicine at universities in Zürich, Munich and Geneva. He became certified to practice medicine at Zürich and received his doctoral degree through the Institute of Anatomical Pathology at the University of Geneva in 1921. While working as an assistant physician at the University Hospital of Zürich (1920-1921), he specialized in internal medicine and psychiatry. He became interested in psychoanalysis while an analysand of Oskar Pfister in Switzerland. He moved to Baltimore, Maryland, in 1921 and obtained U.S. citizenship in 1929. Although the United States remained his primary residence, he maintained close personal, professional and business contacts in Switzerland, France, Germany, and Italy.

Under Adolf Meyer, Syz began work at the Henry Phipps Psychiatric Clinic of the Johns Hopkins Hospital in 1922. He was engaged in both clinical work and research in experimental psychology and taught at the Johns Hopkins Medical School. Here Syz met Trigant Burrow, initiating a long friendship and intellectual collaboration. Burrow, who had studied with Carl Jung and would serve as president of the American Psychoanalytic Association (1925-1926), held an adjunct position at Johns Hopkins at the time.

Starting in 1924, Syz participated in the experimental group-analytic summer camps organized by Burrow in Merrill County, in New York's Adirondack Mountains. In 1927, as an outgrowth of these community meetings, Burrow established the Lifwynn Foundation for Laboratory Research in Analytic and Social Psychiatry. The foundation acquired a permanent research and administration staff and occupied two offices, in New York and Connecticut. Syz's considerable financial contribution was crucial to both the establishment and maintenance of the foundation.

Conceived as a `living laboratory,' the approximately twenty participants of the summer camps were to study their daily interactions in order to shed light on the `noxious' social processes that they believed to be the root of individual neuroses. The research during the foundation's first decade represents an early attempt to enlarge the methods of psychoanalysis to include group interaction, predating mid-century studies of group dynamics and family therapy. The participants, led by Burrow and Syz, came to the conclusion that what their contemporaries identified as normal social roles and behaviors were unauthentic and pathogenic. Convinced that `normal' socialization entailed a divisive individualism and fostered interpersonal aggression (such as that witnessed in World War I), they attempted in these sessions to alter their patterns of interaction. On the basis of these sessions, Burrow proposed a group approach to psychotherapy and social conflict he called 'phyloanalysis'. He and Syz continued to develop and refine this approach in several publications.

Syz moved his practice to New York in 1927 and divided his time between research and administration at the foundation and psychiatric work at several New York hospitals. While the foundation would become Syz's primary research affiliation, he maintained an active involvement in both private and outpatient clinical practice. Between 1930 and 1962 he served in a number of clinics, including the Child Guidance Clinic of the New York State Psychiatric Institute and the Payne Whitney and General Medical Outpatient departments in the New York Hospital, as well as instructing in psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College. He was also an active member in numerous professional and academic organizations. In 1939, Syz married Emily Burrow, the daughter of Dr. Trigant Burrow. They resided near the Lifwynn Foundation in Westport, Connecticut and had two sons, John Devereux (b. 1941), and Stephan Bryan (b. 1947).

The phyloanalytic approach advanced by the Lifwynn Foundation did not gain the broader audience that its members had anticipated, and Burrow was excluded from normal professional circles. Syz remained the foundation's primary interface with mainstream psychiatry and psychology, and his talks at conventions often featured presentations and interpretations of Burrow's thought and research methods. Despite his productivity, with the outbreak of WWII, Syz became somewhat disillusioned with the ability of the foundation's research to effect large-scale social change. His research turned towards more microscopic and physiologically-grounded processes. In collaboration with other staff members, he sought physiological correlates (in, for instance, eye movement, breathing, heart rate, galvanic skin response, muscle tone) to different states of awareness. This research had a social component in so far as it aimed to reduce interpersonal tension by affecting its basis in physiological habits. One instrument he helped develop, the Lifwynn eye camera, is now housed at the Smithsonian Institution.

In the 1950s the Lifwynn Foundation was dealt a severe blow by the deaths of several founding members, including Clarence Shields (1951), Trigant Burrow (1950) and William Galt (1954). In 1951, at the age of fifty-four, Syz assumed the position of president of the foundation, a position he held for approximately forty years. Syz and other surviving members first occupied themselves with editing and publishing unfinished work by Burrow and Galt. Syz continued to lecture on the social theory, research program, and therapeutic strategies he and Burrow developed. With the greatly reduced scientific staff, however, the volume of research and writing at the foundation decreased substantially.

In 1962, Syz retired from the New York Hospital and Cornell University Medical College. In the years immediately following his retirement, he devoted his energies to the placement, cataloguing and exhibition of his ceramics collection. Syz was a devoted collector of 18th-century European porcelain, and between 1941 and 1963 assembled 15,000 pieces representing nearly all major European factories. He published several articles based on his collection. His scholarship in ceramic arts documents Far Eastern influences on European decoration and design. In 1963, Syz donated his collection to the Ceramics Department of the Smithsonian Institution and helped organize its first exhibition in 1966. The Smithsonian Institution named Syz an Honorary Fellow in 1965. Syz continued to write and direct the foundation until his death in 1991 in Greens Farms, Connecticut.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in six series: I. General Files, 1917-1991. II. Notes, 1915-1982, n.d. III. Writings and Research Materials, 1911-1987, n.d. IV. Clinical Files, 1922-1981, n.d. V. Lifwynn Foundation Files, 1912-1988, n.d. VI. Ceramics Files, 1942-1990, n.d.; and one addition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The General Files consist principally of correspondence between Syz and his colleagues in psychiatry and medicine. Other correspondents include professional organizations, literati, students and associates of the Lifwynn Foundation, and friends of the Syz family. The files are arranged alphabetically, and a guide to the correspondence prepared by Syz in folder one provides some topical indexing. The series contains little correspondence of a personal nature. Most folders include both incoming and outgoing correspondence. Other material in the files include memoranda of meetings, clippings, reprints, manuscripts and newsletters. The bulk of correspondence falls between 1926 and 1981.

The majority of correspondents represented in the collection are practitioners in psychiatry and related mental health professions, many of whom engaged in work on social psychiatry or group analysis. Among the colleagues with whom Syz debated the scientific and human value of his `phylobiological' research programme were Leo Berman, Oskar Diethelm, Iago Galdston, Edward Humphreys, Harold Kelman, Adolf Meyer, Walther Riese, Saul Rosenzweig and Philip Woollcott.

The correspondence contains several dialogues on group analytic or group therapeutic approaches to psychiatry. Syz began exchanging letters with Nathan Ackerman, a prominent family therapist, when the latter agreed to write a preface to Burrow's posthumous Preconscious Foundations of Human Experience . Less extensive correspondence on group analysis exists with J. L. Moreno and S. H. Foulkes. Syz's lengthy and theoretical exchange with Nina Bull, author of Attitude Psychology , gave rise to a paper present in unfinished form in Series III. Additional material on Bull can be found in the 'Associates' file of Series V. The files of Tina Keller, who, like Burrow, studied under Carl Gustav Jung, will interest students of the history of psychoanalysis. Keller's recollections of Jung can be found in Series V.

A subset of Syz's correspondents who were developing humanistic and existential approaches to psychiatry also influenced Syz's views on the nature of psychotherapy. These included, in Europe, Gustav Bally, Ludwig von Berthalanffy, Ludwig Binswanger and Ludwig Klages, and in North America, Rollo May. The files of several lay correspondents also contain rich philosophical dialogues on the social bases of mental health and distress. Among the most notable are the files of Iris Gelletti, a scholar who translated selections of Burrow's work into Italian, Christa Hurttlen and A.K. Larsen.

Beginning in the 1960s, the Lifwynn staff corresponded with individuals and groups who were seeking new ways to understand and change interpersonal relationships. Goddard Binkley describes his work with the Alexander technique. Alexander Luncan discusses the feasibility of LSD studies and the Gurdjieff-Ouspensky system. Gerhard Hirschfeld describes his work with the Council for the Study of Mankind. Series V contains additional correspondence on these topics. Other correspondents outside Syz's immediate professional circles included evolutionist L. L. Whyte, literary critic Herbert Read, philosopher Frits Staal, historian Leo Schelbert, and Alfred Korzybski and Marjorie Kendig, who headed the General Semantics movement. The series also records a meeting between Syz and Albert Einstein to discuss Burrow's approach to contemporary social problems.

Some files contain notes from lectures and courses that Syz attended. The files of Alfred Adler and Eugen Bleuler contain lecture notes from Syz's days as a medical student in Austria and Germany. There are, in addition, notes issuing from Syz's frequent attendance at the New School for Social Research in New York. Notes taken during lectures by Kurt Goldstein, Erich Gutkind, Rollo May and Henry Margenau can be found along with correspondence in their folders.

A number of the files supplement material on Lifwynn staff in Series V. Material relating to Lifwynn staff members Lloyd Gilden, William Galt and Bjorn Merker can be found in both Series I and Series V. The files of Maurice Greenbaum provide additional information on the financial and legal affairs of the foundation. Correspondence generated by other staff members of the foundation, as well as inter-office correspondence, can be found in Series V.

Some material has been removed from these files until 2026 June 1 to protect individuals' privacy. Cross-references to restricted folders are provided for most such files. The small quantities of material removed from folders 51-55, 88-91, 114-120, 171-181, 195-198, and 247-254 have not been cross-referenced.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series comprises three kinds of notes kept by Syz: autobiographical sketches, topical notes and reading excerpts. Syz's autobiographical notes contain introspective commentaries on his research, events in the Lifwynn community and his family life. The topical notes and excerpts are more directly related to his writings, and carbon copies from these files can be found among the notes and drafts of many papers in Series III. The collection of reading excerpts consists primarily of quotations from and summaries of books and articles, and are rarely accompanied by critique or commentary.

The autobiographical writings are arranged chronologically. Of particular interest to researchers investigating the activities of the Lifwynn Foundation are the extensive notes written between 1928 and 1929, which comment on the early experiments in group analysis at the Lifwynn camp. These reflections complement the transcripts of group analytic discussions ("Table Notes") of Series V. The notes Syz wrote following his retirement, between 1962-1968, offer his retrospective look at his career and speculations on the future of the Lifwynn Foundation. Related material can be found in Syz's unpublished reflections on the Lifwynn Foundation in Series III.

The topical notes form the basis of Syz's research projects and writings, and are a good source of information for researchers interested in Syz's intellectual development. Syz's original collection of topical notes is preserved in its alphabetical arrangement by subject heading. These typically contain telegraphic paper outlines, memos, bibliographies and clippings. A short series of notebooks and binders ("Topical binders") containing brief annotated bibliographies and reading lists for papers in progress is appended to the first set of topical notes. A second set of topical notes is arranged by date. These follow a standardized format and contain thumbnail sketches of research questions and more thorough formulations of the theoretical reflections found in the autobiographical notes. The formulation of these notes seems to have been an important part of Syz's everyday research activities, as he compiled them steadily between 1925 and 1974.

The collection of excerpts developed by Syz and other members of the Lifwynn Foundation was also used extensively in Syz's writing projects. They are arranged alphabetically by author's name. If an excerpted piece had multiple authors, it is listed under the name of the first author. The few excerpts from presentations made at conferences or panels are listed under the name of the sponsoring organization or the name of the meeting's chair. They are drawn primarily from published books and articles but occasionally from radio and television programs, lectures, unpublished writings, and correspondence. The selections are informative in so far as they reveal what aspects Syz considered to be the most interesting or relevant of the many authors he read. Although the majority of the excerpts date from between 1950 and 1965, they also reflect the evolution of his interests. Early excerpts concentrate on neurobiological and psychoanalytical publications. Beginning in the 1930s, excerpts from writings in a wider range of human sciences, such as Gestalt and evolutionary psychology, anthropology and sociology, become more prevalent. Authors who constituted Syz's immediate intellectual community (those writing about group psychotherapy and social psychiatry) are particularly well-represented.

The excerpts are distinguished from memos of conversations with individuals, which are located in Series I under the name of the interviewee, and conference reports made by Lifwynn staff members, which are located in Series V.

A subject index of the excerpts can be found at the end of the series. Syz had originally kept two series of excerpts, one organized alphabetically by subject and one by author's name. These were merged, but because the two versions were not identical, the subject index is not completely comprehensive.

did.unittitle: Organic - functional [clinical notes on organically- based pathology]
Literature [annotated bibliography, arranged alphabetically by topic]
Miscellaneous problems [telegraphic notes and annotated bibliography]
Miscellaneous topics [binder containing alphabetically organized topical notes]
Various comments [notes on authors and topics, often dated]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of material generated by the writing of Syz's articles, books, essays, reviews and research reports, and are arranged into three sections: published writings, unpublished writings, and data records. With the exception of the data records, which were used in the preparation of several published and unpublished papers, the materials used in the research and writing process are included with the manuscripts to which they relate. This material has been arranged to follow as closely as possible the order in which it was produced (e.g., notes followed by drafts, typescripts and revisions). Syz's writings on ceramics are located in Series VI.

Published writings are organized by type of material and date of publication and include thirty-two articles, two books and fourteen reviews. The first file of the section contains citations of and references to Syz's papers collected by the Lifwynn staff.

The first nine folders of the unpublished writings contain plans and abstracts for unwritten papers. These are organized by date. Because the span dates of Syz's unpublished works tend to overlap, the manuscripts in the remainder of the series are arranged alphabetically by title or heading. Titles are enclosed in quotation marks, while works in progress having no final title are classified on the basis of provisional headings used by Syz, without quotation marks (e.g., Acta paper, Basic reorientation). Manuscripts that were given both a provisional heading and a final title are arranged according to the title, with headings cross-referenced. The manuscripts exist in various stages of completion. Some papers, while not printed, were read at conferences or other professional meetings; other projects remain in the form of notes. Unpublished articles, reviews and book-length manuscripts are interfiled in this section.

A handful of longer manuscripts, including 'Phyloanalysis,' `Studies in Phyloanalysis,' `Applications,' and `Therapy' seem intended as books or monographs; chapter or section breaks are indicated where known. Other plans for larger works can be found under the heading `Trigant Burrow's Thesis' and `Notes for Book'. Three longer works, 'Annotations,' 'Basic Awareness and Being,' and 'Monograph' were written during the preparation of Syz's philosophical memoirs, Of Being and of Meaning (Vom Sein und vom Sinn). It seems that Syz had originally intended these notes to serve as the core of a larger work, including his reflections on his career and the Lifwynn Foundation. For readers interested in Syz's biography, these unpublished drafts are valuable supplements to Of Being and of Meaning.
The data records derive primarily from the studies in physiological psychology Syz performed at Johns Hopkins. Rorschach records used in his clinical research can be found in Series IV.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material in this series consists primarily of patient case notes and case presentations, notes on clinical protocol, research files, course outlines, and minutes of staff meetings deriving from Syz's psychiatric work in several clinics and a private practice. They are organized according to the name of the institution at which they were created. Case material that could not be assigned to a particular institution is at the end of the series.

The files follow the progression of Syz's career from his earliest work as researcher and practitioner at the Phipps Clinic at Johns Hopkins University through his practice in New York City at the New York Hospital and the New York State Hospital. The detailed notes Syz took during staff conferences from 1931 to 1961 provide a participant's perspective on debates taking place in psychiatry in a circuit of major New York psychiatric institutions. These transcripts can be supplemented by notes specifying guidelines for client interviews, treatment, and in some cases the case notes themselves. The files also include class instruction notes from his university teaching and further Rorschach research at the Lifwynn Foundation. See Syz's paper "An experiment in inclusive psychotherapy," (1954) in Series III for a report on how his work at the foundation influenced his psychotherapeutic practice. Series III includes other papers based on clinical research. Some of the relevant case materials are restricted.

did.unittitle: Johns Hopkins Hospital, Henry Phipps Psychiatric Clinic
Case records of patients receiving Rorschach tests
Payne Whitney Clinic notes on staff conferences and case presentations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of papers which document the mission, research, and finances of the Lifwynn Foundation. It is arranged in six sections: General files; Staff files, Staff research notes; Associates' files, Correspondence and Conference notes. The files, which complement materials in the Lifwynn Foundation Records (MS 1681), reflect Syz's role in administering the foundation. They constitute a rich resource for researchers interested in the foundation's history and operation.

The General files at the beginning of the series contain by-laws, budgets, and statements of purpose, which were issued by the staff as declarations on the foundation's mandate. The yearly budgets reveal the substantial contributions made by staff members to support the foundation. Of particular note are records specifically related to group analytic sessions, including transcripts and memoranda of group meetings, which are can be found under the heading "Staff meetings and workshops." This section also includes correspondence exchanged between the foundation offices in New York and Connecticut.

The Staff files, which are organized alphabetically, principally document the research activities of various staff members. They contain writings, notes, proposals, clippings and some correspondence. Research notes and manuals used by the entire staff for collaborative projects can be found the end of this section. Most long-term staff members are represented in the files, though the quantity of material pertaining to different individuals varies. The files of Alfreda P. Sill and Charles B. Thompson, which document of the early group analytic meetings, will be of particular interest to researchers interested in the establishment of the foundation. The Associates' files contain similar information on scholars whom the staff consulted on a regular basis.

The series includes a run of correspondence, which contains copies of outgoing letters written by staff members, principally Alfreda Galt in her role as secretary of the foundation. Only a few incoming letters are included in these files. Much of this correspondence is with individuals and groups exploring alternative approaches to fostering mental health. Correspondence with Gene Dawson, Michael Sperber and David Yandell, who explored the achievements of Trigant Burrow in their graduate work, would interest researchers investigating more recent appraisals of Burrow's thought.
Conference and meeting notes include reports to the staff by individuals on their attendance at workshops and professional meetings. These are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Syz's files relating to his ceramics collection. They are arranged in five sections: General; Writings on ceramics; Correspondence; Dealers and active factory representatives; Museums and institutions. The first ten folders provide a detailed account of Syz's acquisition of the collection, including contacts and invoices, and materials concerning Syz's eventual disposition of it. Various reviews and writings about the collection can be found here. Syz's writings about his collection follow. Syz was particularly interested in Oriental sources for ceramic decoration and interfactory borrowing within Europe. Based largely on the pieces in his own collection, Syz published a series of scholarly articles on ceramic decorations. Reprints of these, as well as notes and correspondence relating to them, can be found here, as can reviews for and correspondence and notes concerning the production of the award-winning Catalogue of the Hans Syz Collection: Vol. I. Meissen porcelain and Hausmalerei.

The bulk of the series is composed of files containing correspondence and other materials with a variety of individuals and institutions interested in the production, collection, or study of ceramics. This material is organized under the headings "Correspondence with individuals," "Dealer and active factory representatives files,"and "Museums and institutions." Staff of other museums wrote to Syz requesting photographs of pieces in his collection, and Syz contacted these institutions and collectors while researching his own articles. The files for the Ceramics Division of the Smithsonian Institution are particularly extensive and document the transfer of Syz's collection to its stewardship. They also provide a description of the Smithsonian's plans to exhibit the collection and include photographs from the opening night, October 29, 1966.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are restricted for reasons of privacy until June 1, 2026.
